subject: Re: Order of execution for tests
msgSnippet: ... Based on personal feedback from promoting JExample the issue of overwhelming mass-failure of tests seems to be well known. People that confirm it to me
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Kent Beck <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> How rare/cheap does this situation need to be before it isn't worth investing
> in the better answer? Put the other way, how frequent/expensive does this
> situation need to be before it is worth investing in the better answer?

Based on personal feedback from promoting JExample the issue of "overwhelming
mass-failure of tests" seems to be well known. People that confirm it to me
are typically working in large teams and/or maintaining code written by
others. Alas, I can offer anecdotical evidence only.

Furthermore, I often hear that developers can (alas) not use JExample since it
is an *invasive* solution. On the one hand this might just be a polite
rebuffal to not hurt my feelings :) but on the other hand is seems reasonable
that in large corporate projects adding a new external dependency is likely
to need approval from project management, which again is typically denied for
below-the-radar projects such as JExample. So exactly the kind of projects
that are likely to suffer from overwhelming mass-failure are unable to move
towards a solution---unless of course it were non-invasive. That is, either
based on tool support only (using e.g. code coverage to detect dependencies)
or being shipped as part of the regular JUnit distribution. (But even then,
many corporate projects don't upgrade to newer versions of JUnit either.)

So my personal conclusion is that if you want adoption by the conservative
Java community you'd better write a non-invasive tool than a framework. All
in all, as someone that knows both the Smalltalk and the Java community I
cannot avoid noting that Jave is starting to get stuck in the same state of
innovation inertia as Smalltalk. As a contrast consider the PHP community
that picked up and integrated the ideas of JExample as soon as they learned of
our XP paper! Or also, the Ruby community that releases and integrated novel
and *awesome* testing frameworks every half year or so. Just think of RSpec,
Cucumber, et cetera. But then, given that TextMate is your upper boundary for
tools you'll naturally look for frameworks rather than tool support :)

--AA
